required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Prospective Evaluation of Interscalene Nerve Catheters vs. Single Injection Blocks
clinical_study.official_title: Continuous Interscalene Block (CISB) Versus Single Injection Interscalene Block in Those Undergoing Shoulder Surgery in the Ambulatory Setting

brief_summary.textblock: The primary hypothesis is that those patients who choose an interscalene catheter will have less pain postoperatively than those with single injection blocks. Secondary hypotheses examine physical therapy outcomes and incidence of parasthesia or pain following surgery for up to 3 months.

clinical_study.why_stopped: The study was halted prematurely due to low enrollment and anticipation of future barriers to enrollment.

primary_outcome.description: Pain score on post-operative day 1(POD1) using numeric rating scale (NRS)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status 1-3
- 18-79 years of age, inclusive
- body mass index of < 36 kg/m2.
- The ability to understand local anesthetic related complications and care of a CPNB
- Presence of a caretaker with them during the first 24 hours of local anesthetic infusion, and on a daily basis.
- The ability to communicate with the practitioner managing the catheter.
- Residence within 2 hours of University of Wisconsin Hospital and Clinics
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any contraindication to a continuous interscalene catheter placement
- Clinically significant pulmonary disease
- Clinically significant cardiac disease
- Allergy to ropivacaine
- Peripheral or central nervous system disease
- Current (or planned) anticoagulation therapy or disease
- Local infection over area of catheter placement
- Renal or hepatic failure
- History of opioid dependence
- Significant psychiatric disease
- Pregnancy or lactation (Subjects will be asked if it is possible they could be pregnant. If a subject responds in the affirmative, a pregnancy test will be done.)
- Seizure Disorder
